shapes

Class Game

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.awt.Component
      • java.awt.Container
        • java.awt.Panel
          • java.applet.Applet
            • shapes.Game
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, javax.accessibility.Accessible

    public abstract class Game
extends java.applet.Applet
    A game built using the Shapes framework.

    Game is one of the two most important classes (along with Shape) for building a game using the Shapes framework. To make a game, you will subclass Game and override the setup() and update() functions. In setup(), you will write code that will execute when your game begins, and in update() you will write code that executes once per frame.

    Game also has a few useful static methods and constants. For example, you can call Game.getAllShapes() to get all the shapes that currently exist in your game. (In case you haven't encountered static methods before: if you see a method named method listed as static below, then you can call it with Game.methodName().)

    See Also:
    Serialized Form

        Parameters:

    • Method Detail

      • init

        public void init()
        You can ignore this method. This method is used internally to initialize this game as an applet.
        Overrides:
        init in class java.applet.Applet

      • ready

        protected void ready()
        You can ignore this method. This method gets called by the subclass's constructor when it has finished initializing, but that call is already written in MyGame.java.

      • setup

        public void setup()
        This method gets called when the game begins, and you should override it in your subclass. Put any code here that you want to execute at the beginning of the game and never again, such as creating shapes and setting background color.

      • update

        public void update()
        This method gets called once per frame, and you should override it in your subclass. Put any code here that you want to execute every frame to update the state of the game, such as moving shapes and making shapes say things.

      • getAllShapes

        public static Shape[] getAllShapes()
        Returns an array of all shapes currently in the game.
        Returns:
        an array of all shapes currently in the game.

      • setLayer

        public static void setLayer(Shape shape,
            int layer)
        Set the layer that a given shape will be displayed in. Since the shapes in this game are two dimensional, it must be decided which will appear "on top" when two shapes overlap. The shape in the higher layer will appear on top.

        Setting a shape's layer will only affect how it is displayed; a shape's layer has no effect on how it interacts with other shapes. (For example, two shapes can touch even if they are in different layers. See Shape.isTouching(Shape).)

        Parameters:
        shape - the shape whose layer is being set.
        layer - the layer into which this shape will be moved.

      • getLayerOf

        public static int getLayerOf(Shape shape)
        Get the layer that the given shape is in. See setLayer(shapes.Shape, int) for more information about layers.
        Parameters:
        shape - the shape whose layer index will be returned.
        Returns:
        the index of the layer that shape is contained in.
        See Also:
        setLayer(shapes.Shape, int)

      • setTitle

        public static void setTitle(java.lang.String title,
            int duration)
        Displays the given title in the game window. Displays title in the center of the screen. While the title is being displayed, no shapes or other text will be displayed, and no update() functions will be called. To display text while other things are displayed, see setSubtitle(java.lang.String, int) or Shape.say(java.lang.String).
        Parameters:
        title - the text to display.
        duration - the number of frames the title will be displayed.

      • setSubtitleStyle

        public static void setSubtitleStyle(TextStyle subtitleStyle)
        Sets the visual style of the game's subtitles. See setSubtitle(java.lang.String, int) for more about subtitles.
        Parameters:
        subtitleStyle - the new visual style of the game's subtitles.
        See Also:
        setSubtitle(java.lang.String, int), getSubtitleStyle()

      • getSubtitleStyle

        Returns:
        the visual style of the game's subtitles.
        See Also:
        setSubtitle(java.lang.String, int), setSubtitleStyle(shapes.TextStyle)

      • setSubtitle

        public static void setSubtitle(java.lang.String subtitle,
               int duration)
        Displays the given subtitle for a given duration. Displays subtitle centered in the bottom of the screen. Only one subtitle can be displayed at a time.
        Parameters:
        subtitle - the text to display. Won't display any subtitle if subtitle is null.
        duration - the number of frames the subtitle will be displayed.
        See Also:
        setSubtitle(String), getSubtitle()

      • setSubtitle

        public static void setSubtitle(java.lang.String subtitle)
        Displays the given subtitle until it is cleared. Displays subtitle centered in the bottom of the screen. Only one subtitle can be displayed at a time. To clear the subtitle, either set a new subtitle or set it to null.
        Parameters:
        subtitle - the text to display. Won't display any subtitle if subtitle is null.
        See Also:
        setSubtitle(String, int), getSubtitle()

      • getSubtitle

        public static java.lang.String getSubtitle()
        Returns the subtitle currently being displayed.
        Returns:
        the subtitle currently being displayed, or null if no subtitle is being displayed.
        See Also:
        setSubtitle(java.lang.String, int)

      • setBorderBehavior

        public static void setBorderBehavior(Game.BorderBehavior behavior)
        Set the behavior of shapes when they reach the game window's borders. The options are:
        • NONE: allow shapes to leave the window.
        • SOLID: prevent shapes from leaving the window. (See Shape.setSolid(boolean).)
        • BOUNCE: make shapes bounce when they hit the window borders, i.e., reverse direction as if bouncing off a physical border.

        Usage example: Game.setBorderBehavior(Game.BorderBehavior.SOLID);

        Parameters:
        behavior - specifies how shapes will act when they reach the border of the window.

      • getBorderBehavior

        public static Game.BorderBehavior getBorderBehavior()
        Returns the behavior of shapes at the game window's borders. The options are:
        • NONE: allow shapes to leave the window.
        • SOLID: prevent shapes from leaving the window. (See Shape.setSolid(boolean).)
        • BOUNCE: make shapes bounce when they hit the window borders, i.e., reverse direction as if bouncing off a physical border.
        Returns:
        a BorderBehavior specifying the way shapes react when they reach the border of the window.
